For the first ten years of its history, the Johns Hopkins University
had no alumni organization of any
kind and doubtless felt no need of
one, for the number of graduates was
small. However, in 1886 the tenth anniversary of the opening of the institution was regarded as an important
milestone and was celebrated with
considerable seriousness. As part of
this celebration a luncheon was held
in the gymnasium, attended by faculty, students, and alumni, and, of
course, enlivened by speeches. After
the speaking Associate Professor
Craig, one of the most brilliant of
that notable group of original Fellows, moved "that an organization of
graduates of the University be
formed." His motion was carried and
a committee of ten was appointed to
put it into effect.
Only three members of that committee are living, and those three are
residents of Baltimore and well known
in its history: W. H. Howell, A.B. '81;
Ph.D. '84; John Glenn, Jr., A.B. '85;
and Allan McLane, A.B,'86. The Committee presented its report on February 22, 1887, when a constitution was
adopted and Allan Marquard, Ph.D.
'80, then professor of art at Princeton,
was elected as the first president.
After the usual Commemoration Day
exercises the Society assembled at the
St. James Hotel for the first alumni
dinner. Josiah Royce, Ph.D. '78, one
of the four earliest graduates and
long a distinguished professor of
philosophy at Harvard, was the second president, and Woodrow Wilson
was the third.
203 Alumni In First Ten Years
At the end of the first ten years
there had been 203 graduates, 119
with the A.B. degree and 84 with the
Ph.D. A study of the activities of all
former students—of course, a much
larger number than the recipients of
degrees—showed that 178 had engaged in teaching, 80 had studied
medicine, 38 were preachers, and 34
lawyers. In the new association the
Ph.D. graduates, though less numerous, were more influential and more
active, in spite of the fact that most
of them were also graduates of other
colleges, which might have been assumed to have first claim on their
loyalty.
As years passed the association
continued its activities, with some decline, I suspect, in the dignity and
sobriety of its annual dinners. Twenty-five years after its first meeting,
the University was faced by many
new problems. The long-awaited removal to Homewood was imminent;
the creation of a school of engineering was under consideration; and the
status of the College in the new surroundings was a matter of serious debate. As one contribution to the solution of these problems the association offered a wholly new venture—
the establishment of an alumni magazine. It was clearly recognized that
there might be less solidarity among
Hopkins alumni than among the
graduates of a university like Harvard or Yale, in which the college
tradition was ancient and dominantly established. It was hoped that the
new periodical would tend "to keep
alive the Hopkins spirit among all
classes of our alumni." To give this
spirit meaning and value an Alumni
Council had shortly before been created with the thought that it would
occasionally meet with the Trustees,
and the hope was expressed that it
would exercise a strong influence
upon the destinities of the University.
The magazine is still in existence and
has fulfilled the expectations of its
founders, though the same can hardly
be said of the Alumni Council.
Active Alumni Desirable
The editors of the NEWS-LETTER
have asked me to give my reasons for
thinking a live alumni association at
Hopkins desirable. The historical
sketch which I have just given is my
first reason. An organization that
once commanded the respect and support of men like Royce and Wilson
must have had something to commend
it. An organization that has persisted for half a century, even though
moribund for the past decade, can
hardly be unworthy of our serious
attention today. To me, at
it
seems a cause for real regret that the
twentieth century has not built more
worthily upon the foundation laid by
the nineteenth.

this Saturday? It's not often that
even the old timers get to see four
teams such as Mt. Washington, St.
John's, Hopkins, and B. A. C. play in
a season, no less in one afternoon.
That is just the opportunity you have
for Saturday afternoon.

the new National Champion. The outcome of the first game will without

champions will come from the collegiate ranks or from the all-powerful
club aggregations. It does not, however, seem probable that the B. A. C.

cope with the strength of the college
teams, to the extent of overwhelming
them. The college units will no doubt
do all within their power to score victories, for the feuds between all-star
clubs and school teams are bitter ones.

INTRAMURALS
Everywhere the coming of spring
inaugurates a new baseball season,
and at Hopkins it means the starting
of the Interfrat and Intramural
leagues, under the able guidance of
Reuben Baer. This year there are 37
teams, which will see action one day
a week on five diamonds in various
parts of the campus.
To date there has been only one
week of play. The Frosh A. B. defeated the Soph Electricals by a 28-13
score and the T. A. 0. beat the Phi
Alphas, scoring 22 runs to the Alphas' 9. Other victories were posted
by 0. K. 0. in the Frat league and
by the Senior Dorms and June GasCivils in the Intramural race.
Without a doubt the Wednesday
Intramural League has included in
its fold some of the best teams in
the school. They are the Senior Dorms,
Soph Hot-Shots, Soph Mechanicals,
and Junior Gas-Civils, the last year
winners. The Dorms took second honors last season, while Soph Mechanicals copped the third position. Other

combines showing enough ability to
be contenders for the title are the
Frosh A. B., Engineers A, Swats, and
New Jersey All-Stars. The Stars were
rained out on their first appearance
but this group is always considered
as a threat.
Mr. Baer expressed the hope and
expectation that the interfrat and
intramural program for the spring
will be characterized by as much success as the fall and winter activities
were. He has been pleased by the
manner in which some of the teams
have organized themselves into wellformed clubs. To cite examples, such
teams as Senior Dorms, Junior Engineers, and New Jersey All-Stars have
been represented on the gridiron, the
basketball court, and baseball diamond.
At the same time Reuben Baer announced that a new system of refereeing interfraternity baseball has
been instituted. It consists of a lone
representative from each frat who
officiates at each game.

Dr. Robinson, renowned archaeologist and lecturer, has in the last
decade proven himself one of the most
prolific authors in the Johns Hopkins
University. Besides the• present histol'y of Greece, which is his seventeenth full-length volume; Dr. Robinson has to his credit well over three
hundred magazine articles. It is interesting to note that the book has
been dedicated to Isaiah Bowman,
"Executive, Geographer, Instigator to
Investigation, Humanist and Friend."
Perhaps one's first reaction in seeing the title of the book, A Short History of Greece, is that here is something superfluous, an unnecessary addition to an already large selection of
volumes on the subject. Even a cursory perusal of Dr. Robinson's book,
however, will reveal the fact that it
is valuable for several reasons. First,
in its brevity it performs a service
to the lay reader and to the student
of elementary Greek history; and at
the same time it avoids the other extreme of being too incomplete or too
sketchy. Second, Dr. Robinson has
stepped outside the customary pale
of history. Not only has he covered
the orthodox ground of ancient history, but he has taken into account
modern developments in archaeological and epigraphical research, and
has made a specific effort to point out
the debts owed by modern literature
and civilization to Greece.
It is the latter point which forms
the most interesting phase of the
volume. Dr. Laurence Foster, of the
University of Pennsylvania, in a brief
foreword, says that A Short History
of Greece " . . . is the first book on
Greece to be written from the point
of view of civilization. Hence it is
unique. In addition to covering the
traditional ground, the book takes
due account of all contemporary research . . . The work is a coordinated
unit with sections on art, literature,
and philosophy as well as general
history. In order to lend true historical perspective, Professor Robinson
has shown the influence of the Greeks
on succeeding civilizations. All of the
various phases of Greek life are treated on such a high level of scholarship
that the book is by far the most scholarly work in its field."
Of course, it was to be expected that
Dr. Robinson would devote a fair portion of his history of Greece to the
story of Olynthus, for the discovery
and excavation of which he will undoubtedly be long remembered. As a
matter of fact, at least twenty pages
out of two hundred, are devoted to
the results of one of the most astounding and significant excavational discoveries of modern times, which

"I did not want, and still do not
want, to write a "proper autobiography," said Miss Stern. And she did
not!
Here is an autobiography that differs from others in its resolution to
avoid conventionalities, to escape all
the dulling, whimsical, over-intimate
orthodoxies of genuine biography.
Working on the hypothesis that a life
story is essentially the description of
a mind rather than the narration of
a personal history, Miss Stern decided, in writing the book, merely to use
herself as her subject and to write
"with as much of myself as possible
to be left out."
The result is a charming and witty picture of a human mind and a
human temperament. Monogram reduced itself to a comparatively disunited, rambling series of commentary, observation, associations, wit,
people, places, and thoughts—all the
results of the association of ideas.
Miss Stern, in her very first paragraph, states her purpose when she
promises to avoid taking a straight
line and the shortest distance between
two points. Instead she chooses three
random points, connects them, and
explores the enclosed area of the resultant triangle. Perhaps the idea is
best expressed in a bit of dialogue
taken by the authoress from a Marx
Brothers film:
"It is my opinion that the missing
picture is hidden in the house next
door."
"But there isn't a house next door."
"Then we'll build one!"
Even the interesting roaming of
Miss Stern's mind, however, does not
keep her from describing a few details of her . family and family life.
But these are, after all, the least important part of the volume. In Monogram, Miss Stern writes brilliantly
on a great variety of subjects, on literature and life, on theatres and people, on an almost incredible selection
of subjects. It is notable that from
modern life the authoress draws a
particularly pessimistic moral: "swift
logic, decisive action, ruthless effici
ency, hundred per cent organizationi
and the result nonsense."
Miss Stern relates a particularly
savory "legend called Hollywood",
which is worth repetition. It seems
that a "voluptuous star went to see
the 'Invisible Man' film, and was so
delighted with the acting of the lead
that she asked for an introduction.
Several months later (in a legend
called Hollywood) she was seen walking down Sunset Boulevard, wheeling
a perambulator with absolutely nothing in it."—W. D.

For the first ten years of its history, the Johns Hopkins University
had no alumni organization of any
kind and doubtless felt no need of
one, for the number of graduates was
small. However, in 1886 the tenth anniversary of the opening of the institution was regarded as an important
milestone and was celebrated with
considerable seriousness. As part of
this celebration a luncheon was held
in the gymnasium, attended by faculty, students, and alumni, and, of
course, enlivened by speeches. After
the speaking Associate Professor
Craig, one of the most brilliant of
that notable group of original Fellows, moved "that an organization of
graduates of the University be
formed." His motion was carried and
a committee of ten was appointed to
put it into effect.
Only three members of that committee are living, and those three are
residents of Baltimore and well known
in its history: W. H. Howell, A.B. '81;
Ph.D. '84; John Glenn, Jr., A.B. '85;
and Allan McLane, A.B,'86. The Committee presented its report on February 22, 1887, when a constitution was
adopted and Allan Marquard, Ph.D.
'80, then professor of art at Princeton,
was elected as the first president.
After the usual Commemoration Day
exercises the Society assembled at the
St. James Hotel for the first alumni
dinner. Josiah Royce, Ph.D. '78, one
of the four earliest graduates and
long a distinguished professor of
philosophy at Harvard, was the second president, and Woodrow Wilson
was the third.
203 Alumni In First Ten Years
At the end of the first ten years
there had been 203 graduates, 119
with the A.B. degree and 84 with the
Ph.D. A study of the activities of all
former students—of course, a much
larger number than the recipients of
degrees—showed that 178 had engaged in teaching, 80 had studied
medicine, 38 were preachers, and 34
lawyers. In the new association the
Ph.D. graduates, though less numerous, were more influential and more
active, in spite of the fact that most
of them were also graduates of other
colleges, which might have been assumed to have first claim on their
loyalty.
As years passed the association
continued its activities, with some decline, I suspect, in the dignity and
sobriety of its annual dinners. Twenty-five years after its first meeting,
the University was faced by many
new problems. The long-awaited removal to Homewood was imminent;
the creation of a school of engineering was under consideration; and the
status of the College in the new surroundings was a matter of serious debate. As one contribution to the solution of these problems the association offered a wholly new venture—
the establishment of an alumni magazine. It was clearly recognized that
there might be less solidarity among
Hopkins alumni than among the
graduates of a university like Harvard or Yale, in which the college
tradition was ancient and dominantly established. It was hoped that the
new periodical would tend "to keep
alive the Hopkins spirit among all
classes of our alumni." To give this
spirit meaning and value an Alumni
Council had shortly before been created with the thought that it would
occasionally meet with the Trustees,
and the hope was expressed that it
would exercise a strong influence
upon the destinities of the University.
The magazine is still in existence and
has fulfilled the expectations of its
founders, though the same can hardly
be said of the Alumni Council.
Active Alumni Desirable
The editors of the NEWS-LETTER
have asked me to give my reasons for
thinking a live alumni association at
Hopkins desirable. The historical
sketch which I have just given is my
first reason. An organization that
once commanded the respect and support of men like Royce and Wilson
must have had something to commend
it. An organization that has persisted for half a century, even though
moribund for the past decade, can
hardly be unworthy of our serious
attention today. To me, at
it
seems a cause for real regret that the
twentieth century has not built more
worthily upon the foundation laid by
the nineteenth.

Everywhere the coming of spring
inaugurates a new baseball season,
and at Hopkins it means the starting
of the Interfrat and Intramural
leagues, under the able guidance of
Reuben Baer. This year there are 37
teams, which will see action one day
a week on five diamonds in various
parts of the campus.
To date there has been only one
week of play. The Frosh A. B. defeated the Soph Electricals by a 28-13
score and the T. A. 0. beat the Phi
Alphas, scoring 22 runs to the Alphas' 9. Other victories were posted
by 0. K. 0. in the Frat league and
by the Senior Dorms and June GasCivils in the Intramural race.
Without a doubt the Wednesday
Intramural League has included in
its fold some of the best teams in
the school. They are the Senior Dorms,
Soph Hot-Shots, Soph Mechanicals,
and Junior Gas-Civils, the last year
winners. The Dorms took second honors last season, while Soph Mechanicals copped the third position. Other

combines showing enough ability to
be contenders for the title are the
Frosh A. B., Engineers A, Swats, and
New Jersey All-Stars. The Stars were
rained out on their first appearance
but this group is always considered
as a threat.
Mr. Baer expressed the hope and
expectation that the interfrat and
intramural program for the spring
will be characterized by as much success as the fall and winter activities
were. He has been pleased by the
manner in which some of the teams
have organized themselves into wellformed clubs. To cite examples, such
teams as Senior Dorms, Junior Engineers, and New Jersey All-Stars have
been represented on the gridiron, the
basketball court, and baseball diamond.
At the same time Reuben Baer announced that a new system of refereeing interfraternity baseball has
been instituted. It consists of a lone
representative from each frat who
officiates at each game.

Dr. Robinson, renowned archaeologist and lecturer, has in the last
decade proven himself one of the most
prolific authors in the Johns Hopkins
University. Besides the• present histol'y of Greece, which is his seventeenth full-length volume; Dr. Robinson has to his credit well over three
hundred magazine articles. It is interesting to note that the book has
been dedicated to Isaiah Bowman,
"Executive, Geographer, Instigator to
Investigation, Humanist and Friend."
Perhaps one's first reaction in seeing the title of the book, A Short History of Greece, is that here is something superfluous, an unnecessary addition to an already large selection of
volumes on the subject. Even a cursory perusal of Dr. Robinson's book,
however, will reveal the fact that it
is valuable for several reasons. First,
in its brevity it performs a service
to the lay reader and to the student
of elementary Greek history; and at
the same time it avoids the other extreme of being too incomplete or too
sketchy. Second, Dr. Robinson has
stepped outside the customary pale
of history. Not only has he covered
the orthodox ground of ancient history, but he has taken into account
modern developments in archaeological and epigraphical research, and
has made a specific effort to point out
the debts owed by modern literature
and civilization to Greece.
It is the latter point which forms
the most interesting phase of the
volume. Dr. Laurence Foster, of the
University of Pennsylvania, in a brief
foreword, says that A Short History
of Greece " . . . is the first book on
Greece to be written from the point
of view of civilization. Hence it is
unique. In addition to covering the
traditional ground, the book takes
due account of all contemporary research . . . The work is a coordinated
unit with sections on art, literature,
and philosophy as well as general
history. In order to lend true historical perspective, Professor Robinson
has shown the influence of the Greeks
on succeeding civilizations. All of the
various phases of Greek life are treated on such a high level of scholarship
that the book is by far the most scholarly work in its field."

"I did not want, and still do not
want, to write a "proper autobiography," said Miss Stern. And she did
not!
Here is an autobiography that differs from others in its resolution to
avoid conventionalities, to escape all
the dulling, whimsical, over-intimate
orthodoxies of genuine biography.
Working on the hypothesis that a life
story is essentially the description of
a mind rather than the narration of
a personal history, Miss Stern decided, in writing the book, merely to use
herself as her subject and to write
"with as much of myself as possible
to be left out."
The result is a charming and witty picture of a human mind and a
human temperament. Monogram reduced itself to a comparatively disunited, rambling series of commentary, observation, associations, wit,
people, places, and thoughts—all the
results of the association of ideas.
Miss Stern, in her very first paragraph, states her purpose when she
promises to avoid taking a straight
line and the shortest distance between
two points. Instead she chooses three
random points, connects them, and
explores the enclosed area of the resultant triangle. Perhaps the idea is
best expressed in a bit of dialogue
taken by the authoress from a Marx
Brothers film:
"It is my opinion that the missing
picture is hidden in the house next
door."
"But there isn't a house next door."
"Then we'll build one!"
Even the interesting roaming of
Miss Stern's mind, however, does not
keep her from describing a few details of her . family and family life.
But these are, after all, the least important part of the volume. In Monogram, Miss Stern writes brilliantly
on a great variety of subjects, on literature and life, on theatres and people, on an almost incredible selection
of subjects. It is notable that from
modern life the authoress draws a
particularly pessimistic moral: "swift
logic, decisive action, ruthless effici
ency, hundred per cent organizationi
and the result nonsense."

delighted with the acting of the lead
that she asked for an introduction.
